subject: Re: Digest Number 778
msgSnippet: You know, Lauren, I think we all agree, it is just a matter of semantics. When I think of TDD, I think of test, code, test, code, refactor, repeat (or
messageBody:
You know, Lauren, I think we all agree, it is just a
matter of semantics.

When I think of TDD, I think of "test, code, test,
code, refactor, repeat" (or something like that). You
are opening it up to that plus the contribution of
more tests by an independent source. Of course you
are right, that is the way to go. I just didn't group
these outside tests under the "TDD" umbrella.

I think J. B. makes a good distinction by not calling
them all "unit tests" but "programmer tests" and
"integration tests". Again, this comes down to
semantics, and I can see independent testers
contributing to either type of test, though typically
an organization defines their job as doing
acceptance/integration tests. But, you are probably
right that they can and should contribute at the
programmer tests level as well.

Oh, and I know your pain on management that is not
receptive to XP (or agile of any sort). That is why I
do TDD; it is the one thing I can do independent of
all other things. I think coworkers notice, and see
the value of TDD as well, to some degree. Maybe
management will some day too, and get curious as to
other potential agile methods.

--- Lauren Bish wrote:
> That is all true - but I didn't say that a dedicated
> unit tester's purpose
> was to replace TDD - what I said was that the
> dedicated unit tester helped
> in getting more and better tests earlier. A
> dedicated unit tester also helps
> introduce the concept and value of unit and early
> testing to teams,
> management, companies and developers. This helps get
> your foot in the door.
> You have to remember that there are a lot of
> companies out there that don't
> practice XP or even halfway decent practices, and
> you can't make them
> swallow XP or TDD all in one gulp. The purpose of
> any good practice is to
> improve the quality of software, but you can't
> accomplish that in one fell
> swoop.
